awd_titl_txt: CSR: EAGER: Quality-of-Experience-Aware Runtime Optimizations for Heterogeneous Multi-Core Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Given the pervasion of consumer devices in diverse operating environments, with a myriad of heterogeneous device resources and applications, designers can no longer pre-define optimization goals (e.g., maximum performance, minimum energy, Pareto optimal tradeoff, etc.) given extremely diverse end-user quality-of-experience (QoE) expectations (e.g., expected user-touch input response time, global positioning system (GPS) accuracy, video playback quality, battery life, etc.). To customize device operation, users typically can only select high-level system settings (e.g., screen brightness, power saving modes, etc.). This coarse-grained method ignores fine-grained configurable parameters with high QoE adherence potential.

In this project, we will explore adapting fine-grained configurable parameters, ranging from cache configuration and pipeline issue width, to more efficient task scheduling in heterogeneous multicore systems, to use of different algorithm/process variations trading off reduced accuracy for increased battery life. Since allowing users to specify this level of device configurability is impractical, future devices must contain an automated runtime optimizer with functionality, architecture, and methods to change the device configuration to rapidly and accurately adapt, predict, and adhere to user QoE expectations.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Given the pervasion of consumer devices in diverse operating environments, with a myriad of heterogeneous deviceresources and applications, designers can no longer pre-define optimization goals (e.g., maximum performance, minimumenergy, Pareto optimal tradeoff, etc.) given extremely diverse end-user quality-of-experience (QoE) expectations (e.g.,expected user-touch input response time, global positioning system (GPS) accuracy, video playback quality, battery life, etc.).To customize device operation, users typically can only select high-level system settings (e.g., screen brightness, powersaving modes, etc.). However, this coarse-grained method ignores fine-grained configurable parameters with high QoEadherence potential, ranging from cache configuration and pipeline issue width, to more efficient task scheduling inheterogeneous multicore systems, to use of different algorithm/process variations trading off reduced accuracy for increasedbattery life. Since allowing users to specify this level of device configurability is impractical, the major goals of this research isto explore fundamental architectural and algorithmic support to empower future devices to autonomously change the device configuration to rapidly and accurately adapt, predict, and adhere to user QoE expectations. Achieving this goal requiresresearch thursts in two major directions: efficient and accurate adaptive design exploration methods and explore acceptabilitymodeling using specialized binary-classification methods for automatically classifying and predicting a configuration?s acceptability.

 

Additionally the project investigated the use a symbolic regression as a machine-learning approach that could meet all of theoptimization goals and constraints. Specifically, the project requires an accurate classification and regression technique thatprovides high accuracy with low computational complexity, in addition to working well with small training sets. We havedemonstrated that symbolic regression is very effective in this use case. For classification, symbolic regression achievedsimilar accuracy as neural nets with 114x fewer operations. For one example, we showed that symbolic regression trainedwith only 20 samples was 7.2x more accurate than a neural net trained from 5000 samples. For regression, we showed thatsymbolic regression was able to discover models that were 19.2x more accurate than existing linear-regression techniques.


Last Modified: 10/29/2021
Modified by: Ann Ramirez
por.por_txt_cntn:
Given the pervasion of consumer devices in diverse operating environments, with a myriad of heterogeneous deviceresources and applications, designers can no longer pre-define optimization goals (e.g., maximum performance, minimumenergy, Pareto optimal tradeoff, etc.) given extremely diverse end-user quality-of-experience (QoE) expectations (e.g.,expected user-touch input response time, global positioning system (GPS) accuracy, video playback quality, battery life, etc.).To customize device operation, users typically can only select high-level system settings (e.g., screen brightness, powersaving modes, etc.). However, this coarse-grained method ignores fine-grained configurable parameters with high QoEadherence potential, ranging from cache configuration and pipeline issue width, to more efficient task scheduling inheterogeneous multicore systems, to use of different algorithm/process variations trading off reduced accuracy for increasedbattery life. Since allowing users to specify this level of device configurability is impractical, the major goals of this research isto explore fundamental architectural and algorithmic support to empower future devices to autonomously change the device configuration to rapidly and accurately adapt, predict, and adhere to user QoE expectations. Achieving this goal requiresresearch thursts in two major directions: efficient and accurate adaptive design exploration methods and explore acceptabilitymodeling using specialized binary-classification methods for automatically classifying and predicting a configuration?s acceptability.

 

Additionally the project investigated the use a symbolic regression as a machine-learning approach that could meet all of theoptimization goals and constraints. Specifically, the project requires an accurate classification and regression technique thatprovides high accuracy with low computational complexity, in addition to working well with small training sets. We havedemonstrated that symbolic regression is very effective in this use case. For classification, symbolic regression achievedsimilar accuracy as neural nets with 114x fewer operations. For one example, we showed that symbolic regression trainedwith only 20 samples was 7.2x more accurate than a neural net trained from 5000 samples. For regression, we showed thatsymbolic regression was able to discover models that were 19.2x more accurate than existing linear-regression techniques.
